channel.title: One Word Titles
channel.description:
Anybody else bothered by how almost every Auxy song has a one word title? They start to seem bland after a while. There are a million songs called "waves" or "lost", and they just seem kind of generic. I would much rather listen to a song called Ghost Waves or Lost Within the Mind. Just my thoughts.
Edit: I seem to have left this out, but I think one word titles are fine sometimes, just wish it wasn't every single time

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: Indigoo
item.description:
I’ve been trying to make interesting titles lately, as you can tell with my 2 newest original tracks.

Read full topic

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
NotMiles:

a light, dainty waltz with oboes and whatnot in a song titled “Furious Deathpunch Killzone”

Aah, yes. One of Brahms’ lesser-known pieces.
Part of his blue period, if I’m not mistaken.
Marvelous! Marvelous!

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: NotMiles
item.description:
LimeZ:

because the name means absolutely nothing in a song

Totally disagree. The title can give listeners an a idea of what mood to expect in the song. Do you expect to hear a light, dainty waltz with oboes and whatnot in a song titled “Furious Deathpunch Killzone”? Probably not. Since I try to write songs that represent a certain place or phenomenon, so I choose titles that “set the scene” for the song.

Read full topic

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: tornait
item.description:
But I name most of my songs after places and abstract ideas, though. Mostly based on location, like for example Hangtime and Current were composed during plane trips.

item.description:
I am fine with song names like Candy or Antidisestablishmentarianist with Antidisestablishmentarianistic Ideas For Antidisestablishmentarianism (both are fake songs) because the name means absolutely nothing in a song (sometimes).

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: BlaMeese
item.description:
I prefer smaller titles honestly. It makes cover art look better and it’s easier to remember. I think as long as the title goes well with the song than it doesn’t really matter that much.

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
No disagreement there. The guy kinda rewrote what is was to be an electronic music producer.

I was a major, major listener back in the early days, including all the alt projects and releases. Back then, you could only get his stuff in the UK as imports (because UK labels weren’t interested).

Aphex (and BoC) were part of the uniform for a (then) young graphic design student, when it was more about the IDM than the EDM, though the track titles were more unintelligible, than intelligent.

Read full topic

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: DontPartyWithGuns
item.description:
One word names are good, it just depends on how original the word is.

For instance, my song whoosis.

But sometimes longer names can be fun. (i.e. step it up a notch and midnight alley)

Read full topic

item.title: One Word Titles
item.dc:creator: Eswyn
item.description:
A lot of mine aren’t uploaded yet, but I keep all of my songs names mostly unique. I have a bunch of Finished songs that I’m publishing soon, including:

  • Mr. McScratchington
  • Mismatched Incorrections
  • Somewhat Tinted Rainfall
  • It’s Called EDM For A Reason
  • The Art of Rethinking
  • Can You H34r Me?
  • I’ll Never Forget You

So yeah. I don’t use generic names much. And when it’s one word, it’s often more unique. Such as my song ‘ffs’ or ‘flake’.

Read full topic
